intro: Guatteria parvifolia var. vestita, commonly known as the white-flowered guatteria, is a species of flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Central and South America. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and related plants, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in shaded, humid environments, often in the understory of tropical forests. Its small, leathery leaves and clustered inflorescences are adaptations to its shady habitat, and it plays a role in supporting local biodiversity. While not widely cultivated, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists due to its unique morphology and ecological significance.
